be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.core

Class Plugin

  • java.lang.Object
    • be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.util.Chain<Plugin>
      • be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.core.Plugin
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Pollable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ClockSynchronizer, ClusterMonitor, ClusterStarter, DashboardSubmitter, EvilPlugin, ExperimentalPropertiesLoader, ExperimentalResultsPublisher, FeatureModelParser, GnuPlotGenerator, HazelcastMonitor, NodeMonitor, RequestReporter, SocketUserHelperPlugin, StabilityMonitor, SummaryGenerator, TimingTestPlugin, UserStopTestPlugin

    public abstract class Plugin
extends Chain<Plugin>
implements Pollable

    Plugins are the fundamental way to extend the functionality of the Scalar platform. Plugins are reflectively loaded based on the Scalar configuration: Every type in the plugins list is instantiated exactly once. The plugin object is then notified via call back methods when specific platform events take place: when the plugin is initialized, when the local Scalar node is started (onInitialization()), when a new experimental run is started (onStartUp()), when the different phases of an experimental run begin (see onWarmUp(), onPeak(), etc.), when an experimental run is finished (onStop(ArrayList)), and when the platform terminates (onTermination()). For real time monitoring, a plugin can also override onRequest(Request) to receive a call back for every Request that has been performed (i.e., for which Request.done(be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.requests.RequestResult) is called). Optionally, a plugin can also enable polling (via enablePolling()) to receive periodic call backs to poll(). Note that polling happens concurrently from another thread, and synchronisation needs to be taken into account. The polling interval is configurable via the internal_polling_interval configuration option.

    Plugins can interact with the platform in three ways. First, a plugin has access to the underlying DataProvider framework, just like User objects, via the data() method. That allows plugins to write data to, and receive data from, user objects. Second, a plugin has access to all user objects that currently exist within the local Scalar instance, via the users() method. Note that not all user objects are necessarily active: During ramp down and cool down, some user objects are stopped, while they are still retained in users(). Third, when an experimental run is finished, a plugin is notified of all Request objects that were created and kept into account (as per User.isKeepingAccountOfRequest(Request)) by the User objects in that run, via the onStop(ArrayList) method.

    Note that plugins are loaded and scheduled to execute in the order in which they appear in the configuration file. If plugin B depends on a task performed by plugin A, A should be placed before B in the plugin list. All plugin objects are executed in the main platform thread. While this avoids the need for synchronization between plugin objects and ensures that all plugin tasks are performed before platform execution proceeds, it also entails that locking up the current thread will lock up Scalar.

    Author:
    Thomas Heyman

    • Method Detail

      • poll

        public void poll()
        Call back method that is periodically (as configured in the config file) called, as long as #pollable() is true. Does nothing by default, can be overridden by subclasses.
        Specified by:
        poll in interface Pollable

      • process

        public final void process(Request r)
        This method is called whenever a request is done (i.e., when Request.done(be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.requests.RequestResult) finishes). Plugins can override onRequest(Request) to specify how a finished request object should be processed. Note that a potentially very large number of request objects is generated, and that the overhead of onRequest(Request) has a very high impact on overall Scalar performance.
        Parameters:
        r - The finished request.

      • startUp

        public final void startUp()
        This method is called when Scalar starts a new run. It is called once for every newly started run, and can be used to perform initialization for individual load tests. In order to specify the startup behavior, override onStartUp().

      • warmUp

        public final void warmUp()
        This method is called when Scalar enters the warm up phase of a load test. Override the onWarmUp() to specify tasks to be performed during the warmup phase.

      • rampUp

        public final void rampUp()
        This method is called when Scalar enters the ramp up phase of a load test. Override the onRampUp() to specify tasks to be performed during the ramping up phase.

      • peak

        public final void peak()
        This method is called when Scalar enters the peak phase of a load test. Override the onPeak() to specify tasks to be performed during the peak phase.

      • rampDown

        public final void rampDown()
        This method is called when Scalar enters the ramp down phase of a load test. Override the onRampDown() to specify tasks to be performed during the ramping down phase.

      • coolDown

        public final void coolDown()
        This method is called when Scalar enters the cool down phase of a load test. Override the onCoolDown() to specify tasks to be performed during the cool down phase.

      • stop

        public final void stop(java.util.ArrayList<Request> allRequests)
        This method is called when Scalar stops a load test. Override the onStop(ArrayList) to specify tasks to be performed after a load test is successfully ended.
        Parameters:
        allRequests - All the request objects that were created by all user objects that were active during this run, i.e., the union of all User.requests() for all user objects that were created and scheduled during this run.

      • terminate

        public final void terminate()
        This method is called only once for every plugin object when Scalar shuts down. Note that this method is also called when Scalar is forcibly shut down (e.g., by pressing ctrl-c). Override onTermination() to specify cleanup behavior that should be performed when the platform terminates. Ensure that this code terminates, if not, normal shutdown of the platform will be impaired.

      • initialize

        public final void initialize()
        This method is called only once for every plugin object when Scalar starts up. It can be used to perform platform specific initialisation tasks. Override onInitialization() to specify initialization behavior.

      • isMasterNode

        public boolean isMasterNode()
        This helper method allows you to easily establish whether this Scalar instance is the Scalar cluster master, or a slave. This is helpful when certain tasks only have to be performed once per cluster, in which case it makes sense to let the master take care of it.
        Returns:
        True if this Scalar instance is the master, false if not.

      • dependencies

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Class<? extends Plugin>> dependencies()
        Specifies the plugin dependencies that this plugin has, if any. Every dependency is specified as a class in the returned list. The Scalar platform will ensure that one instance of every listed dependency has been instantiated before this plugin is instantiated. If one or more dependencies are missing, a MissingDependencyException will be thrown at instantiation time of this plugin. Note that the order in which the dependencies are specified, is not important. By default, a plugin has no dependencies (i.e., the empty list is returned).
        Specified by:
        dependencies in class Chain<Plugin>
        Returns:
        A list containing plugin types that denote the other plugins that this plugin depends on.
